story:
Hi my name is Kristy Lockhart and my best friend was diagnosed with Lyme Disease in 2012 after being misdiagnosed for many years. It took her years and at least 100 doctors/hospital/specialist appointments and visits to finally receive a proper diagnosis.

In March 2014 Heather was 50% better in beating lyme, this has to do with her amazing lyme doctor & her extraordinary chiropractor and naturopath team & her own strength. Heather was on same antibiotics for 18 months, she got bit by ‘something’ weeks ago, ever since then she went from being 50% better to only 10% better with 80% of her previous lyme symptoms returning. She was bit by an unknown bug in late march which caused her ankle to turn red and swell double it’s size, insane itch, she wasn’t able to walk and I took her to the hospital emergency 3 times in one week to get no help, no referrals, nothing. For the last 6 months there was so much improvement, so much hope and light, and now, to be perfectly honesty, we are scared. Physically and neurologically it is as if Heather’s state is as it was before we even started lyme treatment back in September 2012. I have to help her wash her hair, I have to prepare all of her meals, do her laundry and dishes as her joints are swollen, painful and inflamed and she can’t do the things she normally did for the last 6 months as this new ‘infection’ is making all symptoms return that were seemingly gone. We have made an emergency appointment to go back to her lyme doctor only a month after seeing her, as everything we were doing (medication/supplement/etc wise) is no longer working. So far, in 2014 Heather has gotten shingles 3 times & is currently trying to recover from them again. Her immune system is compromised and this is the cause of them recurring.

Thank you to heather’s loving online family, on redbubble and face book, to her friends and even strangers that have donated in the past, shared this link, and supported her with love, kindness and patience and unconditional love during her journey. I couldn’t have helped heather go this far without all of you beautiful souls, and I don’t know what we would do without you. It’s a scary time, Heather likes to put on a brave face, but I myself am not only her best friend, but caregiver and have been watching her rapidly decline over the last few weeks. I need your help now more than ever.

If you know you were bitten by a tick and seek immediate treatment in Canada you go on antibiotics for a few weeks and you’re cured. If you didn’t know you were bit by a tick the tick not only infects you with a devastating bacteria, but it lays its eggs in your body which hatch in 18 days. Heather went almost 4 years in extreme physical pain, I watched her mind and body deteriorate in the most devastating way. Going to every medical appointment, ambulance ride, neurosurgeon, MRI, family dr visit and never getting an answer, having it all blamed on her ‘anxiety’ I decided to take matters into my own hands and researched full time, it was months of extensive research that all signs and symptoms pointed to lyme disease. In Canada treatment beyond a month is NOT available. Chronic lyme is not treated in Canada, and the few doctors who have done so, have lost their license. This is why we have to travel to the USA every 3 months for treatment and expensive antibiotics which are not covered.

The majority of people with Lyme disease are misdiagnosed for years and by the time it is discovered it is almost too late

In 2009 Heather had a gym membership, walked 5 miles a day, hiked, spent time in nature, and constantly doing photo shoots. Now, she can't walk more than 20 minutes, becomes so fatigued far too quickly, has difficulty breathing, chest pains, migraines, her joints swell up so bad she can't write or type, difficulty folding laundry, doing dishes and playing with her cat. Something in her body is malfunctioning as her entire body is covered in edema.

This woman means everything to me. I can't put into words how I love her. She is an amazing artist/photographer (www.locustgirl.comwww.redbubble.com/people/locustgirl) and a genuine pure soul and there's nothing I won't do for her. Meeting someone like this only happens once in a lifetime, and I fear her lifetime will be over soon if her medical treatment is unable to continue.

Donating to this campaign will ensure proper medical care and treatment and lodging while undergoing this care. It doesn't matter if it's $1 or $1000 every little bit helps. Even if you have no $ to donate, please will you post this on various social networking tools to spread the word?

Even while ill, both she and I helped out with other fundraisers (Rideau Valley Wildlife Sanctuary) by donating hundreds of dollars worth of her art to be sold to help treat injured wildlife. She went to college to learn how to take care of the disabled, now she is disabled.

On a happier note, Heather got to spend time with her favorite wild snowy owl this year, snowy momma goddess and this owl was/is the reason why Heather continues to have hope/fight, as 3.5 yrs ago she had lyme and no one would help/diagnose her, and meeting this owl, watching this owl survive and brave the cold ALONE is what motivated Heather to change her life for the better, mentally and emotionally.

-if you look under the tab ‘gallery’ you will see photographs of this beautiful owl and many other wildlife photos that we are offering as a perk, our gift to you for donating.

Please check out her wildlife photography as they will make you fall even deeper in love with wildlife. Heather (when she is able to go out) has this deep soulful connection with animals and it clearly shows in her photography.

She left home at 15 and she has no blood relatives who can help her, and she hasn't worked for years due to being so ill. I am a single woman and the ONLY person who has been helping her for years, please can you help me help her?

Any questions or for a list of the prints you would like, please email me here lockhart_ottawa@hotmail.com

I promise you if you were to meet Heather you would love her almost as much as I do. I have never met another soul with such an enormous loving heart as hers. Please helps us

Love,

Kristy

WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Donating

Perks

$5 - a photograph of heather holding a thank you note with your name on it emailed to you

$15 - a handmade wildlife thank you card with a hand written note to you written by Heather snail mailed to your door.

$20 - a 1 minute audio/voice email of Heather thanking you and acknowledging gratitude for your help

$40 - 8x10 or 8x12 photograph, your choice from the ‘gallery’ tab or her website.

$50 - a personal thank you video made especially to you and a personal handmade card/written and snail mailed to your door.

$100 - 11x14 or 12x18 signed photographic print of your choice from Heather snail mailed to your door

$250 - Ten 8x10 photographic prints of your choice snail mailed to your door

$500 - if you’re in the Ottawa area, I am a gourmet chef, and would be pleased to your cater your event or an intimate meal in your home. (my labor is free, the cost of food would have to be covered by you)

$1000 - if you live in the Ottawa/montreal area, my dear friend has 20 yrs experience as a plumber/electrician, welder and he would work for you for a day doing whatever repairs/renovations you wish.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t contribute financially, that’s okay we understand. Spreading the word via social networking sites helps tremendously.

Always check yourself and loved ones for ticks. They are the size of a poppy seed. Anytime after hiking, camping, out in nature, have your friend to a full body tick check, this could save your life.

MEDICAL BREAKDOWN

Monthly costs in Canada

- travel expenses to medical appointments, pain specialists, etc ( $200)

- vitmans, supplements, tinctures, probiotics of a specific nature ($500)

(none of this is covered, this is all out of pocket)

- chiropractic / naturopathic / acupuncture treatments ($1000)

Every 3 months trip to USA

- travel expenses ($100)

- doctors visit ($500)

- antibiotics ($1500 - $2500)

Tests that are needed that we cannot afford in the USA

- $1000 +
story_txt:
Hi my name is Kristy Lockhart and my best friend was diagnosed with Lyme Disease in 2012 after being misdiagnosed for many years. It took her years and at least 100 doctors/hospital/specialist appointments and visits to finally receive a proper diagnosis. 
In March 2014 Heather was 50% better in beating lyme, this has to do with her amazing lyme doctor & her extraordinary chiropractor and naturopath team & her own strength.  Heather was on same antibiotics for 18 months, she got bit by ‘something’ weeks ago, ever since then she went from being 50% better to only 10% better with 80% of her previous lyme symptoms returning.  She was bit by an unknown bug in late march which caused her ankle to turn red and swell double it’s size, insane itch, she wasn’t able to walk and I took her to the hospital emergency 3 times in one week to get no help, no referrals, nothing. For the last 6 months there was so much improvement, so much hope and light, and now, to be perfectly honesty, we are scared. Physically and neurologically it is as if Heather’s state is as it was before we even started lyme treatment back in September 2012.  I have to help her wash her hair, I have to prepare all of her meals, do her laundry and dishes as her joints are swollen, painful and inflamed and she can’t do the things she normally did for the last 6 months as this new ‘infection’ is making all symptoms return that were seemingly gone.  We have made an emergency appointment to go back to her lyme doctor only a month after seeing her, as everything we were doing (medication/supplement/etc wise) is no longer working.  So far, in 2014 Heather has gotten shingles 3 times & is currently trying to recover from them again. Her immune system is compromised and this is the cause of them recurring.

Thank you to heather’s loving online family, on redbubble and face book, to her friends and even strangers that have donated in the past, shared this link, and supported her with love, kindness and patience and unconditional love during her journey. I couldn’t have helped heather go this far without all of you beautiful souls, and I don’t know what we would do without you. It’s a scary time, Heather likes to put on a brave face, but I myself am not only her best friend, but caregiver and have been watching her rapidly decline over the last few weeks. I need your help now more than ever.
If you know you were bitten by a tick and seek immediate treatment in Canada you go on antibiotics for a few weeks and you’re cured. If you didn’t know you were bit by a tick the tick not only infects you with a devastating bacteria, but it lays its eggs in your body which hatch in 18 days. Heather went almost 4 years in extreme physical pain, I watched her mind and body deteriorate in the most devastating way. Going to every medical appointment, ambulance ride, neurosurgeon, MRI, family dr visit and never getting an answer, having it all blamed on her ‘anxiety’ I decided to take matters into my own hands and researched full time, it was months of extensive research that all signs and symptoms pointed to lyme disease.  In Canada treatment beyond a month is NOT available. Chronic lyme is not treated in Canada, and the few doctors who have done so, have lost their license.  This is why we have to travel to the USA every 3 months for treatment and expensive antibiotics which are not covered.
The majority of people with Lyme disease are misdiagnosed for years and by the time it is discovered it is almost too late

In 2009 Heather had a gym membership, walked 5 miles a day, hiked, spent time in nature, and constantly doing photo shoots. Now, she can't walk more than 20 minutes, becomes so fatigued far too quickly, has difficulty breathing, chest pains, migraines, her joints swell up so bad she can't write or type, difficulty folding laundry, doing dishes and playing with her cat. Something in her body is malfunctioning as her entire body is covered in edema.
This woman means everything to me. I can't put into words how I love her. She is an amazing artist/photographer (www.locustgirl.comwww.redbubble.com/people/locustgirl) and a genuine pure soul and there's nothing I won't do for her. Meeting someone like this only happens once in a lifetime, and I fear her lifetime will be over soon if her medical treatment is unable to continue.
Donating to this campaign will ensure proper medical care and treatment and lodging while undergoing this care. It doesn't matter if it's $1 or $1000 every little bit helps. Even if you have no $ to donate, please will you post this on various social networking tools to spread the word?
Even while ill, both she and I helped out with other fundraisers (Rideau Valley Wildlife Sanctuary) by donating hundreds of dollars worth of her art to be sold to help treat injured wildlife. She went to college to learn how to take care of the disabled, now she is disabled.

On a happier note, Heather got to spend time with her favorite wild snowy owl this year, snowy momma goddess and this owl was/is the reason why Heather continues to have hope/fight, as 3.5 yrs ago she had lyme and no one would help/diagnose her, and meeting this owl, watching this owl survive and brave the cold ALONE is what motivated Heather to change her life for the better, mentally and emotionally.
-if you look under the tab ‘gallery’ you will see photographs of this beautiful owl and many other wildlife photos that we are offering as a perk, our gift to you for donating.
Please check out her wildlife photography as they will make you fall even deeper in love with wildlife.  Heather (when she is able to go out) has this deep soulful connection with animals and it clearly shows in her photography.

She left home at 15 and she has no blood relatives who can help her, and she hasn't worked for years due to being so ill. I am a single woman and the ONLY person who has been helping her for years, please can you help me help her? 

Any questions or for a list of the prints you would like, please email me here lockhart_ottawa@hotmail.com
I promise you if you were to meet Heather you would love her almost as much as I do. I have never met another soul with such an enormous loving heart as hers. Please helps us
Love,
Kristy
WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Donating
Perks 
$5 - a photograph of heather holding a thank you note with your name on it emailed to you
$15 - a handmade wildlife thank you card with a hand written note to you written by Heather  snail mailed to your door.
$20 -  a 1 minute audio/voice email of Heather thanking you and acknowledging gratitude for your help
$40 - 8x10 or 8x12 photograph, your choice from the ‘gallery’ tab or her website.
$50 -  a personal thank you video made especially to you and a personal handmade card/written and snail mailed to your door.
$100 - 11x14 or 12x18 signed photographic print of your choice from Heather snail mailed to your door
$250 - Ten 8x10 photographic prints of your choice snail mailed to your door
$500 - if you’re in the Ottawa area, I am a gourmet chef, and would be pleased to your cater your event or an intimate meal in your home. (my labor is free, the cost of food would have to be covered by you)
$1000 - if you live in the Ottawa/montreal area, my dear friend has 20 yrs experience as a plumber/electrician, welder and he would work for you for a day doing whatever repairs/renovations you wish.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
If you can’t contribute financially, that’s okay we understand.  Spreading the word via social networking sites helps tremendously.  
Always check yourself and loved ones for ticks. They are the size of a poppy seed.  Anytime after hiking, camping, out in nature, have your friend to a full body tick check, this could save your life. 
MEDICAL BREAKDOWN
Monthly costs in Canada
- travel expenses to medical appointments, pain specialists, etc ( $200)
- vitmans, supplements, tinctures, probiotics of a specific nature ($500)
(none of this is covered, this is all out of pocket)
- chiropractic / naturopathic / acupuncture treatments ($1000)

- doctors visit ($500)
- antibiotics ($1500 - $2500)
Tests that are needed that we cannot afford in the USA

story:
Our Mission

Our team of eleven Orthotics and Prosthetics Graduate students from Northwestern University will be traveling to Guatemala for a week long volunteer effort with the community of Zacapa, Guatemala. We will be working with The Range of Motion Project (ROMP) which has fully staffed clinical sites in Guatemala and Ecuador. Our days will consist of clinical evaluations of patients, fabricating prostheses (artificial limbs) and orthoses (walking braces), educating patients on proper wear and care of their prosthetic and orthotic devices and most importantly, giving the individuals in this community the opportunity to walk once again and improve their daily lives. Without the help of volunteer teams like ours working with the ROMP team, these patients would not be able to receive the specialized care they require to return to fully functioning status in their communities.

Team Members:

Dylan Borrenpohl, Home Town: Okawville, IL

Rae Figueroa, Home Town: San Leandro, CA

Dan Hallisy, Home Town: San Francisco, CA

Haris Kafedzic, Home Town: Sarajevo, Bosnia

Brittany Mott, Home Town: Westfield, MA

Nicole Olson, Home Town: Colorado Springs, CO

Jennie Rhodes, Home Town: Dallas, TX

Brodie Rice, Home Town: Gillette, WY

Devin Schlueter, Home Town: Valparaiso, IN

Nick Uhler, Home Town: Lake Zurich, IL

Katie White, Home Town: Lincolnshire, IL


How Can You Help?

ROMP is a non-profit organization that provides free orthotic and prosthetic care to people in developing countries who live with amputations and other physical disabilities. These services are not otherwise readily available to these patients. ROMP operates a full-time clinic in Zacapa, Guatemala, but relies upon trained volunteers from around the world to provide the specialized care that these patients require.  

All of the funds raised from this event will be used to support a trip to this clinic for our team of 11 Prosthetics and Orthotics students from Northwestern University in February. During the course of this trip, we will provide devices to a multitude of patients, imparting them with the lasting mobility and independence they need to lead a productive life and provide for their families far into the future. Your donations will help to:

  • Offset Volunteer Transportation Costs
  • Cover Clinical Operating Costs
  • Subsidize Lodging for Volunteers


The Impact 

In a culture stricken with poverty and violence, the need for prosthetic and orthotic care is overwhelming. With an underdeveloped health care system, many individuals living in Guatemala do not have access to even the most basic health care. The Range of Motion Project provides free prosthetic and orthotic care to individuals in underprivileged areas that are desperately in need.

ROMP operates without regard for religious or political affiliation. This organization strives to support those living in poverty without access to prosthetic or orthotic devices. ROMP recognizes that  prosthetic and orthotic devices are a critical component in the rehabilitation process of persons with disabilities. With these "tools", independence, involvement in community and mobility in the socio-economic structure can become more attainable. Rehabilitation has the power to show that "disability" is only as crippling as the barriers we let stand in our minds and in our world. Together, with the help of trained prosthetists and orthotists, care givers, volunteers and generous donors, ROMP's vision of offering independence and hope to countless individuals is becoming a reality.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that a monetary donation is not always possible. However, if you would like to help our cause in any other way, please feel free to share this campaign with others and visit the ROMP website for more ideas to get involved:

http://rompglobal.org/whatyoucando.html

story:
About Us

Rio Santa Cruz Grassfed Beef (RSC) is a small-scale, family-owned business operated by Duncan and Susan Blair. We raise 100% grassfed beef on a “salad bar” of annual forages crafted for the climate and soils of Santa Cruz County in Southern Arizona. Our calves are born on our ranch in the uplands of the Santa Cruz River. At weaning they are moved five miles to our farm on the Santa Cruz River. Here they live peacefully and naturally on green, grassy forages sustained by irrigation and summer rains. Our cattle live low stress, high quality lives; they are not fed any grains.

We work hard to provide our customers with the best beef we can, but we need to address the long-term sustainability of our enterprise. We have been in business for four years. We have developed and refined our production; and we have met the many challenges of marketing, processing, and storage. We are at a point where the demand for our high-quality, artisanal grassfed beef exceeds our annual production. We've got a ranch, a small cow herd, forage-based bulls, a finishing farm, the necessary skills, and a growing customer base. Now we are ready to expand! 

For us, expansion means more cattle, more customers, and eventually a larger farm. We need more quality calves of our own raising and genetics, and more irrigated land to finish them. Available irrigated land in southern Arizona is very hard to come by; we've been searching and will continue to do so. Meanwhile, please help us expand our cow herd and make the taste and nutrition of premium quality, 100% grassfed beef available to more people. 

The Budget

The money raised from this campaign will go to purchasing heifers to cross with our forage-based bulls so that we can raise more calves for the farm. At the current average price of $1200 per heifer, our budget of $40,000 would allow us to significantly increase the size of our herd.

Why Grassfed?

Compared to conventional beef, grassfed beef is:

1. Better for the environment (less energy goes into growing grass than grain)

2. Better for the beef eater (fewer calories, more healthy omega-3 fats; more antioxidants, beta carotene, vitamins, and minerals)

3. Better for the cattle (our methods are more humane; and who wouldn’t be happier standing around in green fields all day?)

Why RSC Grassfed is Better than Other Grassfed in Arizona

1. We use forage-based genetics. Most modern American beef genetics are focused on weight gain based on grain in a feedlot. Our bulls bring genetics that allow our cattle to thrive on grass and to finish exclusively on growing forages. 

2. Our calves feed on a “salad bar” mix of annual forages. We plant, irrigate, graze and maintain a diversity of  annual forages, alfalfa, and perennial rye grass. What we plant and graze changes with the seasons—from  cool to warm to autumnal. This means that our calves are always on green, growing forages.

3. We irrigate. We start irrigating in February, begin grazing in April, and don’t stop either activity until early November. This enables an extended period of grazing green forages­—longer than other Arizona ranches that feed on range grasses and rely on monsoon rains. RSC is located on the Santa Cruz River and the water we use for irrigation seeps back into the water table from which it came. 

Thank you for your support!

We know that budgets are tight (hence this Indiegogo campaign...) and we appreciate your support. In addition to any financial contribution you can provide, we would love if spread the word! Share this on Facebook, email your friends and family, 'like' the things we post, and generally be a cheerleader for the cause.

Thank you, Duncan & Susan

story:
A little bit about me...

I was born and raised in Greece and I am also half Dutch.  I studied ''Sports science & Physical education'' in the Aristotle university of Thessaloniki in Greece and my passions are  Exercise & Nutrition (since I believe these two are inseparable).  I have been training ever since I remember myself. I competed in my hometowns rowing team and also was a national champion in Canoe-Flatwater in my student years..

 

 What led me into writing a motivational exercise book...

On 2008 I had a big accident which ended up destroying my left leg. What followed was 5 years on crutches, 13 operations, having 4 different external fixators installed in my leg over time, additional health problems and depression.  Before my accident I was pretty lean and muscular but that quickly changed and I ended up losing most of my muscle and becoming overweight. After 13 failing surgeries I understood that my leg wouldn’t be ever fully healed. I had also lost 3 inches of height from my lower leg (tibia bone) which meant I needed to wear shoes with special heels. It not like I didn’t tried… My leg broke 3 times (!) once the bone was fully healed putting my life on hold for something like the 14th time… So I took a big decision, to amputate my leg and go on with my life! The surgery was scheduled for after 6,5 months.

So I decided that if I was going to have to be in a good mental state for this surgery I was also going to have to be in good physical shape. As an athlete most of my life I knew the importance of body and mind connection. As a great master once said ‘’To keep the body in good health is a duty… otherwise we shall not be able to keep our mind strong and clear.”~ Buddha

Going to the gym at the time was not an option at the time so I decided I that I would have to make the best out of a workout plan I could perform at home. Although I was really determined I still had my doubts on how effective it would be in comparison with a gym program which was the environment I was used to training mostly in the past … So I sat down on my laptop and made a plan. I thought of all of the best bodyweight exercises, ways to progress into the ones I couldn’t yet perform and variations for the ones that were too easy. I thought of ways I could use stuff like regular home furniture and backpacks turning them into exercise equipment.

After six months of training both my body & mind really hard, researching new ideas on diet and exercise all the work of training hard and a disciplined diet paid off. I was feeling healthier than ever and my body was in great shape, supporting me that way also mentally for the big challenge that I had to overcome.

 

Why do I need your help?

After my surgery I decided organize the training method I created and put in the form of a motivational and instructional book. The reason I need your help is that I want to hire a professional who will put my book in an e-book format so I can upload it for free on my website (which I am also working on at the moment) for the rest of the world who is interested in it

Any extra money I raise will be invested in offering as much free information I can for the following years on my website, youtube channel and maybe making even more e-books.

 

Other ways you can help?

Even if you like my story but you can afford to invest in my cause there are many ways you can help me. Share this video online , on facebook , e-mails or even mouth to mouth.

 

What do you get?

As I mentioned already I want my e-book to be free for everyone. That means if you invest in my program and I succeed you will be able to download a free copy of my e-book.  People who are looking for a home workout plan like mine which does not require extra expensive training equipment a lot of the times cannot afford training anywhere else  and since I have been in that position I can correlate.

story:
"Whenever I bring a bag of fresh White Sage or Sedona MYST Spray into someone’s home - everyone goes ahhhhh! Moods of the people take a positive shift, a refreshing clarity sweeps the room. Nature has shared its beautiful medicine with me, and it is my joy to share it with you!" David Castiglione - Naturalist

"My name is David. I have spent several years developing an extraction process which enhances the healing and clearing properties of White Sage. The result is Sedona MYST, a revolutionary product which breathes life back into stale, moldy, mildew and fungi prone environments.

I have tested over 3,000 bottles of Sedona MYST in nursing homes, homes, offices, kennels, veterinarian offices, spas, and gyms. The results have been nothing than astonishing!

Sedona MYST now has an opportunity with a company that manages over 500 nursing homes. It has tested our product and loves it. It has asked me for an automatic mist delivery system utilizing our Sedona MYST to clear the air in their facilities and provide a healthier environment for their elders and staff.”

David Castiglione

sedonaalchemy@gmail.com

people take a positive shift, a refreshing clarity sweeps the room.
Nature has shared its beautiful medicine with me, and it is my joy to share it with you!" David Castiglione - Naturalist"My name is David. I have spent several years 
developing an extraction process which enhances the healing and clearing
 properties of White Sage. The result is Sedona MYST, a revolutionary 
product which breathes life back into stale, moldy, mildew and fungi 
prone environments.I have tested over 3,000 bottles of Sedona 
MYST in nursing homes, homes, offices, kennels, veterinarian offices, 
spas, and gyms. The results have been nothing than astonishing!Sedona
 MYST now has an opportunity with a company that manages over 500 
nursing homes. It has tested our product and loves it. It has asked me 
for an automatic mist delivery system utilizing our Sedona MYST to clear
 the air in their facilities and provide a healthier environment for 
their elders and staff.”

David Castiglione
sedonaalchemy@gmail.com

story:
On September 20th, Jerry Hart had a heart attack. Thankfully he acted quickly, and received excellent medical care so the damage to his heart was minimal. He has to have another procedure and is going to be on medical leave until at least November 1st. Jerry does not have paid sick time, and loss of income and medical bills will be a financial hardship for Jerry and his wife.

Anything you can donate to help Jerry and Amanda out would be greatly appreciated!

story:
This is our 2 year old "medical marvel" Vayda Ann. She recieved 3rd degrees burns in our backyard.   She has fought so tough this far and she will soon be undergoing skin graft surgery and needs all the prayers she can get. This has been and will be a long road to recovery.   Here's Vaydas intense story. Thank you

 

         A few weeks ago my sister and mother were in from out of town for my sisters baby shower.  That evening they came over to look at gifts, swim, etc.  I started a fire in  the backyard to help clear out Mosquitos. Right before I went in the house I found a frog and gave it to my other 2 kids(5,7...boys).  My boys, being boys, tried to scare their sister.  She back peddled away from the frog, losing her footing,spinning,falling directly into the fire pit. I had literally walked in the house 10 seconds beforehand.  I was in the house I heard my wife screaming, I look out and she was swooshing my daughter(Vayda) around like crazy In our kiddy pool. I ran out to see what was goin on and my frantic wife raised my daughter out of the pool and her skin was off of her arm and hand and hanging to the ground. Myself, wife, 2 boys, mom and sister were scared to death.

          After a 911 call we ended up at the local hospital, we were then transferred to Detroit Children's Hospital, and thats where the "medical marvel" begins.

       The first thing they had to do was get all of her blisters on her leg, both arms and both hands popped, scraped and cleaned. This was 3 hours of pure pain for our Vayda. She was as medicated as she could be for a 2 year old, and the nurses said it was the worst they had a kid react that they had ever seen. That's saying something coming from a children's hospital. The following day they had to clean and scrape it all again because the night before was so dreadful. They had to put her under. When she awoke, she had an adverse (backwards) reaction. Vayda was totally out of control nonstop for 4 hours. Drs could do nothing but wait for the medicine to wear off.  The following day the Drs.  used a different medicine that they use as a backup to ensure no other adverse reactions.  Needless to say she had another adverse reaction, the first time they ever seen a child react like that to that medicine, again for 4 hours.  The following day they had to put her under one more time......

       The Drs found 3 more 3rd degree burns on her leg, they talked to us and decided they were gonna be much quicker so they would use half of both the medicines. So we agreed.  When Vayda awoke this time she was ok at first. The nurse told us she was doing great and we could leave in a day or two to care for her at our home. Seconds later, she lost it again. We had our 5 year old son Max try to calm her down. She fell asleep instantly. My wife and I said good job max!  A few seconds later our nurse returned and was immediately frantic. We thought Max got Vayda asleep. What happened was, she quit breathing.  

       Next thing u know there's every Dr in the hospital in our room, Max and the furniture are pushed out, my wife and I are screaming and shaking her, the Drs are preparing for CPR and x rays, we are at our brink of emotions, then our little angel starts  breathing again!  She had an unusual reaction to the mixed medication. That's when our Dr said " Vayda you are a medical marvel, you keep doing things we have never seen before day after day"

         Needless to say Vayda made an impact on every Dr in that hospital every day she was there, and she impacts every person she knows with her feisty personality every day she's home.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
It's nice when your doctor knows what it's like to be you.

Hello! I am a first-generation college grad from a low-income family, and over the next year I hope to become one of the tiny handful of individuals who have been admitted to medical school as an out trans person. As a medical student I plan to continue my record of community service and to advocate for LGBTQ issues to my peers and the institutions that train us. Later as a medical doctor I plan to practice primary care with low-income & LGBTQ populations. During my career I also want to engage in basic clinical research in trans and queer healthcare, so that our communities can benefit from the same kinds of evidence-based standards as everyone else. But that goal is still far off, and I could really use some help getting there.

November Update: I got into medical school! Thank you again to everyone who helped here. Without this support I am not sure that I actually would have attended the interview at the school that accepted me, the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health in Madison. All in all I had 6 interviews and I will hear back from two more schools about possible acceptances by the end of the year.

story:
My name is Thelma Mubaiwa and I am 20 years old. HelpTsiti is a campaign that is designed to help bring family from Zimbabwe here to the United States to take care of my aunt. The letter below is a letter that I have been circulating around trying to bring awereness to something very close to my heart as well as my family and Friends. 

To whom it may concern:

We are slowly losing one of the most amazing and influential people our lives to a terrible disease, Breast Cancer. Tsitsi (Tee) Mutseta, My aunt, My hero, My role model, My everything. This woman is not only the best friend and sister to my mother, this woman is my mother too. She grew up in a small village in Zimbabwe where the HIV/AIDS epidemic has taken most her village. After graduating high school, she was an unfortunate victim of human trafficking. Taken from her home and brought to America where she worked as slave for three years. After escaping from where she was held, one would think she would have given up on people and life. Instead my aunt went to San Diego State University to become a nurse. She vowed that she was going overcome her misfortunes and she was going to do so by going to college. This would result in giving her the ability to be able to take care of the family she left back in Zimbabwe. While in America she has lost her father and all 4 of her siblings. Leaving her with the responsibility of being mother to 9 children. In 2005, she started a nonprofit organization named Compassion for African Villages. She has been financially and emotionally supporting: 350 children, 200 are orphans, and 8 school teachers. Although the school they attend in Zimbabwe is in disrepair, the children love going. She has been providing the children with uniforms, school supplies and has been paying the 8 teacher’s salaries.

In April 2007 my mother took my sisters and I to visit my aunt in the nursing group home she worked in at the time. Walking in we were greeted with the smiles and hugs from the older people she took care of. A welcome reflected with love reciprocated from the compassion and care they received from her. My aunt was sitting behind a table with a lot of what I would call schoolwork in front of her. She looked at us and smiled but her smile did not reach her eyes the way it normally would. I immediately knew something was wrong. We sat down and my aunt told us she had been diagnosed with Stage 4 breast cancer. Unrestrained, one by one the tears fell from all of our faces...

Tee was in currently in the middle of attending San Diego University to become a nurse. Slowly but surely this disease attempted to rip her dreams from her very hands. But determined and strong willed as she is, she did not give up and shortly after her diagnosis she graduated from San Diego State University. The cancer forced her to stop working as the chemotherapy and cancer began taking its toll. By the grace of God and family and friends who love and cherish her she has been able to keep her apartment and live what some might consider comfortably.

While battling this disease, Tsitsi makes beautiful hats and scarfs by crotchet knitting that she sells at Kobey’s Swap meet to raise money for her organization and herself. On top of this she also has several gardens throughout San Diego, the produce from the garden she then sells at several farmers markets. Although the medicine helps ease some of the pain from the cancer, Tee finds a different kind of solace in the gardens. Being in her garden places her back in Zimbabwe, in the land and home she grew up in. The garden has become a form of therapy for Tee and even when the medicine is not easing the pain, the garden does a very great job. Recently due to the nature of her cancer she has been unable to function fully in the garden and do what she loves best.

This cancer has now taken a hold of her entire body and she is very very sick. Because she cannot go home and see her remaining family, we would like to bring them here to her in America. We are trying to raise enough money to bring her mother and uncle so they can be there to take care of her. We are asking that you open your hearts and help us reach this goal to help a woman who has spent her entire life helping others. Just as the name of her nonprofit organization let us show compassion for Tsitsi and help to bring her family here. Thank you so much in advance to those who will donate and if you cannot donate even just a prayer would help. Help us make this story viral. Share with a friend, who will share with another friend and sooner than later more than enough people will know. Compassion is contagious, let’s spread it all over!

Sincerely,

Thelma Mubaiwa, family, and friends.

After being refused an emergency visa for 7 years to come to the United States and take care of her sick daughter the visa was approved as of today 5/6/13. We are now on a mission to raise money for her mother and uncle to come as well. The cost for the earliest tickets from Zimbabwe here for two people will be roughly $6,036 for roundtrip tickets give or take a couple hundred dollars.Our goal is to have them here as soon as possible. The remainder of the money will be used as an insurance just in case the ticket prices rise. Also we will need to pay for baggage as well and the food they will eat on the way here.

We understand we are requesting a lot but anything will help. if you cannot donate PLEASE share this story, share this website and help us to get this story viral. We are asking for help to the one person who has helped everyone her entire life. It is now our turn to return the same compassion to her.

story: Mayo Clinic has informed us that we will be there at least a week for outpatient treatment. Our lives were turned upside down over night. She is on unpaid leave from work and I was let go from my job because I was needed by her side. Our 6 yr old son needs his mommy back. He prays every night that her disorder gets treated and her pain goes away. We will be using the money raised for our journey to mayo clinic and medical bills that come with it. Our goal is to have her be able to function on a day to day basis without constant pain. We appreciate any and all donations and support. Thank you all so much!

story:
Bring Birth Centers Back to NJ!

During the NJ BirthNetwork Annual Symposium, attendees identified several areas of focus to improve maternal outcomes and continue implementing Mother-Friendly Maternity Care in NJ.

Bringing birth centers back to NJ was a key foundation piece in that plan.

In an effort to move this agenda forward, we are raising funds to send our chapter leader to the American Association of Birth Centers training in Washington DC.

All funds raised will be used toward NJBN's birth center program work and associated task force efforts.  Thank you for your continued action and financial support in improving maternity outcomes in NJ.

Together we are taking back our birth rights!

_________________________________________________________________________

New Jersey BirthNetwork is a local chapter of BirthNetwork National, a 501c3 organization.  NJBN is engaged in a statewide effort to bring Mother-Friendly maternity care to our state.  This includes increased access to VBAC, birth centers and midwifery care.

NJ families need to know, there is a growing coalition of people and caregivers who support a mother's right to pick her birth location, her maternity provider and her right to informed consent and informed refusal.  There are a wide range of care options for pregnant or birthing women and their families.  NJBN is working to help make these options well known and widely available.

We will accomplish this mission as we:

1. Provide information and education about evidence-based, normal birth practices consistent with Lamaze International's Six Care Practices that Support Normal Birth and the Coalition for Improving Maternity Services (CIMS) Mother-Friendly Childbirth Initiative (MFCI)

2. Assist consumers in identifying professionals, health care providers and facilities that support mother-friendly maternity care practices.

3. Promote awareness and availability of community resources and outreach programs that support normal birth.

story:
Feed the cadets during finals and show your battalion spirit!! 

It's the battle of the battalions!!

The 4th Battalion cadets will be hungry during late night cramming sessions for finals.  Send them tasty gourmet jerky in a variety of flavors to stave off those hunger pangs and fuel their finals prep!  Plus, show the other battalions that 4th Battalion has the most dedicated supporters!

Donate here to fund the 4th Battalion jerky purchase!

Results will be posted on the Facebook pages each week showing how much each battalion has raised to feed the cadets.  

It's a head-to-head competition ... may the best battalion win!

Don't let 4th Battalion be beaten by the rest!  Donate today!

The details: Proceeds will be used to help BSA Troop 160 fund-raise for a trip to Mount Rushmore. Donations (less processing charges from indiegogo) will be used to purchase jerky from Country Meats Smoked Snacks, in a variety of flavors, to be delivered during finals to 4th Battalion.  Jerky sticks are sold and shipped by the case so only full cases will be purchased - leftover funds will be donated directly to the troop. One dollar buys one jerky stick (after processing charges from indiegogo have been deducted).

story:
Short Summary

We are from Alzheimer`s and Related Disorders Association of Ghana (Alzheimer`s Ghana), legally registered NGO in 2012 with the aim of championing dementia in Ghana and providing education and training, care and support for people affected by dementia and their families.

Currently, there is lack of awareness of dementia in Ghana and as a result, people with dementia are being stigmatized, rejected, neglected, abused and socially excluded by the society. Also, there is no differentiation between progressive neurological diseases from normal cognitive decline in old age leading to misdiagnosis. In addition, there is limited health facilities and services to assess and diagnose the disease (no appropriate therapeutic interventions or community support services) and this increase the burden of care on their poor families. Further, many suffering from this disease are maltreated, some burnt to death and others sent to witches camps and opened to inhumane treatment. Contributing towards this will help deal with isolation, neglect and abuse of people with dementia in Ghana.  

The campaign needs $ 27,000 to put up a Day Care Center and run the center to provide  support services for people affected by dementia.

Contributors` names will be acknowledged on our organisation's website and on the crest of the Day Care Center.

The project will help to improve the understanding of dementia by families caring for a relative with dementia; reduce stress for primary carer as they will feel more able to come forward to ask for help.

It will also improve quality of life for persons with dementia – treated with respect and dignity. Communities will be more accepting of people with dementia – improved social inclusion and will reduce stigma, neglect and abuse of older people by families and communities, especially of older women. 

In 2010 alone, the annual cost of dementia was estimated at US $604 billion. That is, if dementia were a country, it would be the 18th largest economy globally. My project will be valuable to the entire world because it will reduce the rate of abuse, proper diagnosis will be made, institutions will be put in place, many will be aware of the disease and this will go a long way to reduce global expenditure on dementia.

Currently, we are the only dementia organisation in Ghana and had previous successful interventions on dementia in the country.

 We have published several articles in the news prints and online (topics include "Victims of Witches Camps could be Sufferers of Dementia", "Education on Dementia needed in Ghana", "Combating Dementia in 21st Century Ghana" among others. Our organisation is a developing member of Alzheimer`s Disease International with Head Office in UK, who provide us with technical  expertise. As part of our advocacy role, we participated in the WHO conference on  scaling-up aging policy in Ghana in 2013. Our work team can be trusted to deliver on this project.

Hi, folks we know that, not everyone would be able to contribute money towards this project, if you are not able to do so, please inform someone about this campaign by using indiegogo share tools . Thank you all for your kind gesture and thoughtfulness.
story_txt:
Short Summary We are from Alzheimer`s and Related Disorders Association of Ghana (Alzheimer`s Ghana), legally registered NGO in 2012 with the aim of championing dementia in Ghana and providing education and training, care and support for people affected by dementia and their families.
Currently, there is lack of awareness of dementia in Ghana and as a result, people with dementia are being stigmatized, rejected, neglected, abused and socially excluded by the society. Also, there is no differentiation between progressive neurological diseases from normal cognitive decline in old age leading to misdiagnosis. In addition, there is limited health facilities and services to assess and diagnose the disease (no appropriate therapeutic interventions or community support services) and this increase the burden of care on their poor families. Further, many suffering from this disease are maltreated, some burnt to death and others sent to witches camps and opened to inhumane treatment. Contributing towards this will help deal with isolation, neglect and abuse of people with dementia in Ghana.  
 The campaign needs $ 27,000 to put up a Day Care Center and run the center to provide  support services for people affected by dementia.
Contributors` names will be acknowledged on our organisation's website and on the crest of the Day Care Center.
 The project will help to improve the understanding of dementia by families caring for a relative with dementia; reduce stress for primary carer as they will feel more able to come forward to ask for help.
It will also improve quality of life for persons with dementia – treated with respect and dignity. Communities will be more accepting of people with dementia – improved social inclusion and will reduce stigma, neglect and abuse of older people by families and communities, especially of older women. 
In 2010 alone, the annual cost of dementia was estimated at US $604 billion. That is, if dementia were a country, it would be the 18th largest economy globally. My project will be valuable to the entire world because it will reduce the rate of abuse, proper diagnosis will be made, institutions will be put in place, many will be aware of the disease and this will go a long way to reduce global expenditure on dementia.

 We have published several articles in the news prints and online (topics include "Victims of Witches Camps could be Sufferers of Dementia", "Education on Dementia needed in Ghana", "Combating Dementia in 21st Century Ghana" among others. Our organisation is a developing member of Alzheimer`s Disease International with Head Office in UK, who provide us with technical  expertise. story:
The Love Company

The Love Company is a small yet big hearted orphanage founded over 3 years ago in Pokhara, Nepal.

Currently we have 13 children, ranging from 3 to 14 years old. 

Some have come from abused homes, some from remote villages, and some have been rescued from the streets of Nepal.

Our children are happy children, but like any child they often get sick. Whether it's getting a major cut while playing outside with friends or catching a fever/cold from the poor conditions at the local school, our kids are often in need of healthcare.

There are many things that go into funding an orphanage: rent, food, school supplies, clothes, etc. 

Often we do not have the funds to cover these things, let alone an impromptu visit to the hospital.  Recent stitching incident:

We love all of our children as if they are our own and their well-being is our top concern.

What We Need

  • We would like to raise $1,000 USD in 2 months to help cover some of our recent medical bills for the children.
  • Any access funds will be set aside in a separate account to maintain in case of future healthcare emergencies at the orphanage.

The Impact

Your contribution will keep our children healthy and happy.  An impact that is difficult to express in words.  For more information about our organization please visit our site at http://thelovenepal.org.np/nepal/

story: My name is Isaiah; I'm a 25-year-old yogi, human rights activist, small-time Brooklyn real estate salesperson and a person of great substance and character who loves to take care of those around me by spreading warmth, love, & positivity wherever the wind takes me. Despite my caring nature, I unfortunately did not practice SELF-love the day of 6/29/2014, four days after my birthday, when I lost my footing while on a fire escape and sustained two calcaneal fractures as well as fractures in my lumbar and thoracic spine. I have been bedridden ever since and had two very extensive & complicated surgeries. I will be bound to a sexy black wheelchair for the next 2-3 months and have many obstacles ahead of me which I know I'll overcome with the right  attitude and a pinch of community support to ensure that I (very literally) land safely on my feet. I'll need help offsetting  the cost of my extensive medical care, assistance with relocation from my 3rd floor walk up apartment where I can no longer live for practical reasons into either a first floor unit or a building with an elevator. Furthermore, I will need home-based assistance and good old fashioned love and patience while I get healthy and learn to walk properly again. Please help out if you can. if you are  broke like most people I know, realize that your company is probably the beat gift of all. Be safe and don't fall! xoxo

story:
Please realize to finish he clinical trial with your small  financial support

If somebody has died from cancer in your family you will understand this invention!

My name is Berthold Zwerger.  I run a research laboratory in immunodiagnosis in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany (southern Bavaria, near Munich).

For 18 years I have been working on a medical invention which can detect all malignant tumors using a single test.

There is currently no comprehensive screening test for detection of all malignant tumors worldwide.

The primary function of this invention is to detect aggressive malignant tumors at an early stage.

The German Cancer Research Institute in Heidelberg (DKFZ) reports that one out of four people will develop a malignant tumor in their lives, and of those 25% are cured.

A key feature of a tumor marker is so-called sensitivity and specificity.  The sensitivity involves the false-negative results in percentage terms; the specificity the false positive results.
Tumor markers currently on the market can only detect a few types.  Furthermore, the sensitivity is low (40-50%) so that they are not very reliable cancer detectors. 
But on top of that, conventional tumor markers are predominantly organ-specific.

I have discovered an immunological phenomen that can identify all malignant tumors using a single test.

A German State Medical Association has already voted positively on the ethics of the tumor detection process, in line with the Helsinki “Ethical Principles for Medical Research Involving Human Subjects” agreement.  An independent physician has also approved the tumor marker.  The hit rate is currently around 97%. 

The test is fully automated and uses standard blood analysis equipment currently available in hospitals worldwide. (These are automated machines that analyse the conventional biochemical status of blood tests.)

The invention does not compete with diagnostic imaging; there is no clue as to where the tumor really lies.  It also does not compete with clinicians, since its main use is to detect cancer earlier and to assist doctors in their diagnosis. 

The values measured in tests correlate to the level of malignancy.  In several tests, it has recognized the body’s response to chemotherapy.  Conventional tumor markers react very slowly and are not suitable for chemosensitivity diagnosis.  Normally the CT images are placed side-by-side in “stagings” where the size of the tumor and treatment are compared.  But until now none of these processes could detect the really aggressive tumor cells. 

Doctors and clinics have already expressed an interest in this invention but are waiting for a full study or a completed product. 

Here is a quote from Global Business Development Manager, one of the largest diagnostic groups in the world: 

"You address with your test an interesting question. However, the development status of your tests is too early for us to enter into a cooperative agreement.  We ask for more extensive validation and peer review in scientific journals.”

Patent protection and, ultimately, the freedom to operate are important elements in our process testing.  Idealy, we’re looking for:

a) patent protection, as well as

b) a completed study, which is broken down into certain tumor types.

I would therefore like to achieve the following goals with this funding request:

1. Seeking people who will continue to post information on this innovation in cancer diagnostics to support the campaign and make them known.  I’m looking for donors who would allow me to complete research into this process. 

2. To complete the study, I need about 1500 samples from cancer-free subjects, as well as samples from newly diagnosed cancer patients who are currently not receiving chemotherapy and have not undergone surgery for any types of cancer.  There are opportunities to buy blood samples from biobanks. The cost of a meaningful study is around € 300,000 ($ 373,000).  I now have the capacity in Garmisch to record 500 patient samples a day but need the necessary capital to start this phase.

3. I need at least one scientist who can analyse all biomolecular readings.

4. Therefore, I am dependent on private donors who recognize the ethical value of this invention for the good of mankind. This is a pioneering academic work, which reflects the cancer-fighting interests of the healthcare industry.  But to achieve industry-wide support, a full study must be carried out that is 100% credible. 

Patients would greatly benefit from this tumor marker.

Some documents, statements and scientific evidence by experts are published on www.carcimun.com, also in English.

You can be sure that all donations and support will go into the research and development of this test.  I would be very thankful if I only could finish the study with the indiegogo campaign.

People who have interest to invest and get shares can contact me directly: info@carcimun.com

Clinics which want to cooperate also can contact me.

Thank you!

story:
As neighbours,  Danielle Arsenault and Jessica Perlaza, discovered their mutual love for cooking by knocking on each other’s door to borrow a pinch of this and a dash of that. Through these moments of sharing food together, they created a series of vegan, gluten-free cookbooks inspired by the seasons.
All recipes found in the cookbooks are vegan and gluten-free and are created, tasted and photographed by the ladies themselves – PINCH and DASH – in their home kitchens.

Since 2011, Danielle and Jessica have been selling their cookbooks all over the world. Being published in Korean "Vogue Girl", Chincha Online, Groove Magazine, Edible Orlando and several others has made the little zines so popular that they have actually sold out - to take a look at some of these publications, check this out!

Now, Danielle embarks upon her own little project which is in fact a collection of raw, whole-food plant based recipes that she's gathered together. These recipes come straight from her Raw Food Education Courses she holds once a year in Canmore, AB, Canada. The new recipe book is called, *Heal and Ignite* because the power of these recipes within, in their true, unheated state actually have great healing powers. They also inspire because they are so delicious and truly do ignite the spirit and get you excited to get in the kitchen and experiment with the most powerful foods we have available to us!


What We Need & What You Get


We are looking for donations to allow us to reprint both the 4 little seasonal books of ours and also to fund the printing process for Danielle's new “cookbook”.

With your donation, you’ll be sure to get your own copies in the mail shortly after they are printed and if you are lucky enough to live in Canmore, Banff or Calgary, Danielle will even drop by your home and treat you and your friends to a delicious gourmet raw food dinner. Take a look at some of the other perks as well.
If we don't reach our entire goal, we will ask for a new quote that includes less books printed. With even a limited amount of money, we can print a short run.


The Impact


We hope to inspire all those food and health enthusiasts out there to get in the kitchen and experiment. We hope that even those with no prior food knowledge nor cooking experience will be excited to implement easy, whole food recipes into their diet and become more aware of the food we choose to nourish our bodies with. Our work has the power to shine a light on food that will heal and provide the most nutrient dense deliciousness in each and every meal. Thank you for your support… so much love to you all!


Other Ways You Can Help


If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. To do this, you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
On July 8, 2014 we will be celebrating 

Marcos' 2 year transplantiversary!

We cannot imagine a better way to celebrate than by providing

Marcos a safe environment to run and play without the fear of foreign

germs and all that comes with them!


Marcos now 2 and 1/2 years old has always been the happiest of boys! His

life since transplant, though joyful has not been without struggle and

complications. He is immunosuppressed and simple colds/viruses 

have put him in the hospital for weeks at a time.

He absolutely loves outdoors and the park, but with each park visit,

despite our best attempts to avoid it, is likely to come a new hospital admission.


Marcos was born 9/20/11 with Gastroschisis (A rare disease that causes

the intestines to develope outside the body) For Marcos, this ultimately lead to the loss of all but 14cm of his small bowel and irreversible damage to the

liver from months of intravaneous nutrition. He spent the first several months of his life fighting to survive in 3 different hospitals, (two of them out of state). Hope was grimm but he persevered, continuing to beat the odds and proving doctors wrong!

On July 8, 2012 at the young age of 10mos Marcos recieved 3 new

organs, and a new chance at life! His Multi-Visceral Transplant

consisted of a Small Bowel, Liver, and Pancreas. In addition to a 6 month stay at a hospital nearly 1000 miles away from home. UNMC.


***Marcos was airlifted 6/5/14 from his home hospital at UNM in

Albuquerque to University of Nebraska in Omaha. He is currently on a

ventilator and his body is fighting hard to come off of it. Help us

show our support for him by providing him his own place where he can

grow and run around free without worry when he gets better!!


Once our goal is reached, any monies fundraised not used for the

purpose of a playplace for Marcos will help go toward current and

future expenses of travel to and from New Mexico and Nebraska. And 5%

of that will be donated to DONATE LIFE.

story:
CLICK ON THE ARROW ABOVE TO WATCH THE VIDEO!

Our Story

Leto Solutions, Inc. is a start-up medical device company based in San Antonio, Texas. We had our origins at the University of Texas in San Antonio as a student project, when a team of four Engineering students and four Business students formed to compete in the University’s $100K CITE (Center for Innovation, Technology, and Entrepreneurship) contest. A requirement of the contest is that the team must design a product, build a working prototype, and create a Business Plan for a successful company.

The team did not need to look far for the inspiration for their “product”. One member of the team is a wounded warrior – Gary lost his leg as a result of injuries he sustained while serving in Iraq with the US Army. Gary told the team that, while his prosthetic limb helped him regain his mobility, it brought unexpected problems.

After Gary challenged the team to find an effective way to cool his prosthesis, the engineers went to work and designed a unique system. A prototype was built and worn by Gary for a few months with amazingly positive results. For the first time, Gary was able to wear his prosthesis without experiencing a build-up of heat and sweat.

The team won the CITE contest, and has received considerable recognition since then: Leto Solutions was named a Top Ten Life Science Company in Texas at a competition sponsored by Rice University; featured in the ABC News “Second Tour” series; and featured in numerous articles in print and online.

Leto Solutions, Inc. was formed in September 2013, and is committed to improving the comfort of wearing a prosthesis and the quality of life for all lower limb amputees.

http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2014/05/u-s-army-veteran-turns-injury-into-innovative-startup/

story:
The Road Back: A Path To Success™

                                        


A Research and Recognition Initiative to Assist Our Veterans with PTS and Related Issues

The Problem

Every year thousands of returning military, state, and local police officers and emergency workers suffer from Post-Traumatic Stress (PTS). PTS is a devastating condition that can destroy lives and despite being “invisible” externally, is as real as a devastating physical wound for those that suffer its disabling effects.

  • Up to 40% of returning veterans affected with Post Traumatic Stress remain untreated.
  • Approximately 2 million children have one or both parents in the military and are potentially impacted by PTS.
  • More than 256,000 veterans who served in Iraq or Afghanistan have been treated for PTS.
  •  PTS costs Americans more than $15 billion annually.
  • Current treatment regimens for US Veterans suffering with PTS have only a 35% success rate.
  • Conventional treatment therapies often mandate drug therapy that  only mask the symptoms and can lead to prescription drug addictions.
  • We lose more Veterans to suicide than combat.  We are losing 22 veterans per day to the "Silent Killer PTS


The Road Back, a Path to Success is an initiative of the Research and Recognition Project. The Goal is to develop and fund our promising scientific treatment that ends Post Traumatic Stress.
 

Our treatment protocol, RTM, decreases the treatment time by over 50% and increases the effectiveness to over 85%. It uses no drugs and is non-invasive.

A $300,000 research program on RTM has been approved by New York State  in a facility adjacent to the former Horton Hospital campus in Middletown.  This funding will run out by the end of September, possibly before we are able to finish the research necessary to bring RTM to all of our Veterans 

After the initial research is completed we hope to convert the facility into a University affiliated full treatment and research center for PTS.

The Road Back, a 501 (c)3 initiative of the Research and Recognition Project, is raising additional funds for more research and a state-of-the-art, self- sustaining clinic to help our veterans. Our goal is to raise $3 million for operating expenses for the first two years, at which point economic self-sufficiency is expected.

PTS is a devastating condition that can destroy lives and despite being “invisible” externally, is as real as a devastating physical wound for those that suffer its disabling effects.

Up to 40% of returning veterans affected with Post Traumatic Stress remain untreated.

story:
Celebrate the legacy of Breaking Bad and the launch of its spin-off with Baking Bad, the unauthorized cookbook. With over 100 recipes, ranging from exploding turtle cake to 5-star gourmet meals, Breaking Bad will become a permanent part of your life.

About the Book:

  • All recipes are provided in a comprehensive step-by-step format assuming no previous experience
  • Strewn with Breaking Bad trivia and quotes
  • All meals provide background info, where relevant.

Divided into 5 Sections:

  • Party Stuff: Snacks and finger-foods guaranteed to please even the most die-hard Breaking Bad fans. Ideal for Halloween parties and all night marathons.
  • Kid Friendly:  Fun opportunities for the younger Breaking Bad aficionados to play with their food.
  • Lunch: Practical meals for your day-to-day Breaking Bad needs.
  • Dinner: Gourmet meals meant to impress. The type of food Gustavo would serve you the first time he invites you to his house.
  • Deserts: Arguably the best section of the book. Here you will find everything from  sky-blue homemade ice cream to teddy bear eyeballs.

story:
Hi, I'm Nana Fifield and I'm raising funds for the Ghana Alzheimer's charity.

This charity is very close to my heart as my Father, a retired professor of Mathematics and Physics, is suffering from this terrible disease.

The Ghana Alzheimer's charity works diligently to raise awareness and funds for its sufferers but needs great support, particularly financially, to continue with its awareness programme in Africa, to train, educate and provide much-needed carer for families and sufferers.

Today, the charity is run by very determined, caring and passionate volunteers.

The goal of this fundraising campaign is to raise enough money for the charity to provide a well-staffed day care centre and community for Alzheimer's sufferers and their families in Ghana.

So please Help us to Make This Happen!
